qas.question: How much of the population in the Middle East died of the plague?
How much of Paris' population was killed by the plague?

answers.text: Half of Paris's population of 100,000 people

qas.question: What do isolated, spaced out graves of plague victims indicate?

answers.text: at least some pre-planning and Christian burials

qas.question: How many people would die of plague in largely populated cities?
Which areas were least vulnerable to disease?
How many people lived in Egypt at the start of the Black Death?
What percentage of monks and priests died from the Black Death?
What percentage of people in isolated areas of Europe died from the Black Death?

context: The most widely accepted estimate for the Middle East, including Iraq, Iran and Syria, during this time, is for a death rate of <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>about a third<a0_2/><a0_1/>.<a0_0/> The Black Death killed about <b8_0>40%<b8_0/> of Egypt's population. <a1_0><a1_2>Half<a1_2/> of <b7_0>Paris<b7_0/>'s population of <a1_1><b5_0>100,000<b5_0/><a1_1/> people<a1_0/> died. In <b6_0>Italy<b6_0/>, the population of Florence was reduced from 110–120 thousand inhabitants in 1338 down to 50 thousand in 1351. At least 60% of the population of Hamburg and Bremen perished, and a similar percentage of Londoners may have died from the disease as well. Interestingly while contemporary reports account of mass burial pits being created in response to the large numbers of dead, recent scientific investigations of a burial pit in Central London found well-preserved individuals to be buried in isolated, evenly spaced graves, suggesting <a2_0>at least <a2_1><a2_2>some pre-planning and Christian burials<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> at this time. Before 1350, there were about 170,000 settlements in Germany, and this was reduced by nearly 40,000 by 1450. In 1348, the plague spread so rapidly that before any physicians or government authorities had time to reflect upon its origins, about a third of the European population had already perished. In crowded cities, it was not uncommon for <a3_0>as much as <a3_1><a3_2><b9_0>50%<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> of the population<b9_0/> to die. The disease bypassed some areas, and the <a4_0>most <a4_1><a4_2>isolated<a4_2/> areas<a4_1/><a4_0/> were less vulnerable to contagion. Monks and priests were especially hard hit since they cared for victims of the Black Death.
